body.p: Cuneiform is designed to be written on clay. The wedge-shaped impressions that give cuneiform its modern name are made by pressing a stylus into the surface of a moist clay tablet. The stylus is then lifted back up ready to make the next impression, rather than dragged across the surface as we would use a pen. Some tablets were enclosed within a clay envelope. And tablets or envelopes were sometimes stamped or sealed. There are strong connections between a language, the writing system in which it is written, the medium on which it is usually written and the technique of writing. The Sumerian and Akkadian languages were typically written in cuneiform script on clay but was also sometimes written on other media.

esp:image.description: Clay moulded into the shape of a clenched human fist, complete with fingernails. Cuneiform text is written down each of the fingers
esp:image.esp:caption: Image 1: This clay hand lists the titles of king Assurnasirpal II. Its first line says it is from "the palace", meaning the Northwest Palace . BM 90976. View large image (193KB). © The Trustees of the British Museum.

body.p: Most cuneiform inscriptions were written on clay tablets. Different shapes and sizes of tablet were used for different purposes, but most fit comfortably in the hand. The Succession Treaties of Esarhaddon are written on unusually large and thick tablets. Various types of clay were used, some containing stones or shells, others with very few inclusions. This is similar to our use of different sizes and qualities of paper for newspapers, letters and post-it notes.

esp:image.description: Two clay foundation cylinders of Assyrian kings, inscribed with cuneiform text
esp:image.esp:caption: Image 2: Left: a typical cylinder of Sargon II, with flattened faces. BM 108775. This example Dur-Šarruken (modern Khorsabad), but Sargon deposited similar examples in Kalhu. Right: a typical cylinder of Esarhaddon from Kalhu, narrower and fully rounded. British Museum BM 131129 (ND1126). View large image. Image: Jon Taylor for the Nimrud Project CC-BY-SA 3.0.

body.p: Clay could also be formed into other shapes for special purposes. Loans of barley were written on triangular dockets. Assyrian kings of the first millennium BC had their inscriptions written on a variety of objects: tablets, cones, bricks, prisms and cylinders. The exact text of each was discussed and carefully chosen. The objects themselves were carefully chosen as well. Two popular types of object chosen to carry royal inscriptions were prisms and cylinders. The size and shape of these varies from one ruler to the next (Image 2). And inscriptions are found even on architectural fittings in the shape of hands (Image 1).

esp:image.description: Some typical shapes for the various types of text found at Nimrud
esp:image.esp:caption: Image 3: Some typical tablet shapes for the various types of text found at Nimrud. View large image. Image: Jon Taylor for the Nimrud Project CC-BY-SA 3.0.

body.p: Scribes also chose certain shapes and sizes for each of the different types of text from daily life. "Conveyances" (such as the sale of slaves or land), for example, are characterised by their portrait format and band of seal impressions across the upper obverse. The more ephemeral contracts (for things such as loans) meanwhile are smaller, landscape format tablets, with envelopes. The envelope was sealed, the tablet not. A typical letter would be portrait format, but thinner than a conveyance and not sealed. Scholarly tablets are often written in portrait orientation, in one or two columns. Image 3 shows some common tablet types from Nimrud.

esp:image.description: Close up of clay tablet section, showing 'inclusions' of other material within the clay. Inclusions of (now decayed) plant matter appear as small holes but stones remain visible in the clay
esp:image.esp:caption: Image 4: Many stone inclusions are present in the clay of this tablet from Kalhu. The tablet itself contains an 8th century BC letter about purchasing horses (translation online: SAA 19:168). British Museum ND 2627. © The Trustees of the British Museum.

body.p: Clay for making tablets was readily available from rivers. So too were reeds for making a stylus. The clay for tablets could first be processed to remove stones and plant matter. This did not always happen, however, and many tablets contain such inclusions (Image 4). Indeed, tablets from Nimrud contain inclusions much more often than those from Nineveh, for example.

Assyriologist Henry Saggs tested the clays of tablets from Nimrud . He found that tablets originally from Babylonia contained a higher level of lime than their Assyrian counterparts. This made them softer, and less likely to suffer cracking, but more susceptible to damage from salts coming to the surface and breaking off text as they crystallised.

esp:image.description: Tablet surface with visible firing holes
esp:image.esp:caption: Image 5: Scholarly tablet of tamītu prayers (CTN 4 62), with visible "firing holes". Despite their name, the exact function of these holes is not known. British Museum ND 4401. © The Trustees of the British Museum.

body.p: Most tablets were not fired in antiquity. Left to dry in the air (preferably not in the sun, which dries them too quickly), tablets become hard enough to withstand normal handling and storage. This means that they could potentially be recycled by melting down the clay in water, although in many cases old tablets were simply discarded. Tablets intended to survive for very long periods could be fired. Such tablets sometimes contain what Assyriologists call “firing holes”, the actual function of which was probably not to assist in the firing process, however (Image 5).

esp:image.description: End view of clay tablet, showing visible individual layers where the sheet of clay has been rolled into a tablet shape
esp:image.esp:caption: Image 6: End view of a tablet, showing visible individual layers where the sheet of clay has been rolled into a tablet shape. This 8th century BC tablet is inscribed with a letter to the king about mules for a postal service (translation online: SAA 19: 141). British Museum ND 2661. © The Trustees of the British Museum.

esp:image.description: End view of tablet, showing a skin of fine clay wrapped around a core of rougher clay
esp:image.esp:caption: Image 7: End view of a tablet, showing a skin of fine clay wrapped around a core of rougher clay. This 8th century BC tablet is a letter reporting on an Ionian raid on a western province of Assyria (translation online: SAA 19: 25). British Museum ND 2370. © The Trustees of the British Museum.

body.p: Many tablets survive only in broken condition. While this obviously means that we have lost some of the text, it does sometimes allow us to see how the tablet was made. Often we can see that the scribe had rolled a sheet of clay into the tablet shape (Image 6). Another technique saw a skin of fine clay wrapped around a core of rougher clay (Image 7).

esp:image.description: Clay tablet with inscribed cuneiform text, with a circular seal stamped three times into the surface
esp:image.esp:caption: Image 8: Cuneiform tablet recording the sale of a slave woman named Arbela-lamur ("May I see Arbela!"). An officer in the crown prince’s retinue has certified the sale by impressing his stamp seal on to the tablet. The tablet dates from the reign of king Assurbanipal , . ND 2325. © The Trustees of the British Museum.

body.p: Seals had long been used to confirm identity or indicate authority. The Succession Treaties of Esarhaddon are sealed with no fewer than three cylinder seals. During the Neo-Assyrian period, old-fashioned cylinder seals gave way to stamp seals (Image 8). Instead of being rolled across the surface, a stamp seal was simply impressed into the clay. Sometimes an old cylinder seal was kept, and was used as though it were a stamp seal.

esp:image.description: Clay tablet with inscribed cuneiform text, which has been 'sealed' using the fingernails of 11 men. The fingernail impressions run in a horizontal row across the top of the tablet
esp:image.esp:caption: Image 9: A row of fingernail ‘signatures’ runs in a horizontal row across the top of this tablet, sealing the document. It records Bel-tarṣi-ilumma paying off a huge debt ("2 talents, 20 minas of bronze") for someone named Sabiri. From Room 6 of the Governor's Palace, 793 BC . ND 211. View large image on British Museum website. © The Trustees of the British Museum.

body.p: Another method of sealing was to use a fingernail. In the tablet shown in Image 9 men impress their fingernail “instead of their seal” to certify that the debts owed to them have been repaid. It has been suggested that some fingernail impressions were made with a special tool.

esp:image.description: Photograph of inscribed clay tablet and the inscribed clay envelope that surrounded it
esp:image.esp:caption: Image 10: Clay tablet (bottom) and its envelope (top). This loan document from 636* BC was excavated from Room 19 of Town Wall house 57, Nimrud . ND 3445. © The Trustees of the British Museum.

body.p: There was a very long tradition in Mesopotamia of enclosing texts within protective envelopes (Image 10). Like a modern envelope, the Assyrian type was made from a folded sheet (although in this case made of clay rather than paper). In the case of a letter, the name of both sender and recipient were written on the envelope, together with a short greeting and a seal impression to confirm the sender’s identity. Few envelopes survive, because the act of opening them meant breaking them; the broken pieces would then be discarded.

The word for stylus is written with signs that mean “tablet reed”. Reed was a natural and very suitable material for a stylus. Traces of the fibres of the reed can sometimes be seen in the wedges of cuneiform. Wood, bone and other materials could also be used. No original Assyrian styluses survive.

esp:image.description: Excavated room within the temple of the god Nabu at Nimrud
esp:image.esp:caption: Image 11: An Assyrian filing cabinet? The archive room in Assurnasirpal II's Northwest Palace during excavations by the British School of Archaeology in Iraq in the 1950s. Photo: BSAI/BISI.

body.p: Mesopotamian scribes stored their tablets in jars, bags or on shelves. Max Mallowan, who excavated in Nimrud in the 1950s, suggested that the feature in archive room ZT 4 of the Northwest Palace should be interpreted as a filing cabinet for tablets (Image 11).
